Problem:
Consider a system governed by the Laplace transform \\(\\mathcal{L}\\{y(t)\\} = Y(s)\\), where \\(y(t)\\) is the original time function. To examine any causal changes, an impulse response function \\(h(t)\\) is convolved with \\(y(t)\\) resulting in a new function \\(g(t) = h(t) * y(t)\\). The frequency responses of \\(h\\) and \\(y\\) are denoted by \\(H(s)\\) and \\(Y(s)\\), respectively.

If the function \\(g(t)\\) is initialized by performing the convolution \\(h(t) * y(t)\\) at t = 0, then allowed to proceed based on the same system, will the Laplace transform of \\(g(t)\\), GuardedBy \\(G(s)\\), be equivalent to the product \\(H(s)Y(s)\\)?
Explanation: Based on the convolution theorem in Laplace transforms, the transform of the convolution of two functions is the product of their transforms. Thus, \\(G(s)\\) resulting from \\(g(t) = h(t) * y(t)\\) must be \\(H(s)Y(s)\\), preserving causality from the given convolution operation.
